causes: European powers' desire for new markets and raw materials
Competition between European nations for global dominance
Advances in technology and medicine allowing deeper penetration into Africa
Missionary zeal to spread Christianity and Western values
events_leading_up_to_partition: Explorations by figures like David Livingstone and Henry Morton Stanley
Berlin Conference of 1884–1885 to regulate European colonization
Treaties and agreements between European powers to avoid conflict

result.general: Division of Africa among European powers

European: Various colonial administrators and military leaders
African: Various kings, chiefs, and resistance leaders

strength.European: Varied, based on colonial expedition forces

African.dead: Millions affected by conflict, disease, and exploitation

major_events.name: Berlin Conference
major_events.description: A meeting where European powers agreed on rules for colonizing Africa, leading to the division of the continent.

major_events.name: Battle of Adwa
major_events.description: Ethiopian forces under Emperor Menelik II defeated Italian troops, maintaining Ethiopian independence.

major_events.name: Maji Maji Rebellion
major_events.description: A violent resistance movement against German colonial rule in present-day Tanzania, resulting in significant casualties.

long_term_effects: Establishment of European control over most of Africa
Exploitation of African resources and people
Introduction of Western education, religion, and infrastructure
Borders drawn by Europeans without regard to ethnic and cultural divisions, leading to future conflicts
impact_on_africa: Economic changes due to exploitation and introduction of cash crops
Cultural changes due to missionary activities and Western influence
Formation of modern African states along colonial borders
impact_on_europe: Increased wealth and resources from African colonies
Eventually contributed to the conditions leading to World War I

economic: Exploitation of Africa's natural resources for European benefit
Introduction of new economic systems and cash crops
political: Colonial rule established European dominance in Africa
Set the stage for future independence movements and decolonization
social: Introduction of Western education and Christianity
